study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association between preoperative nutritional status (measured by PNI) and walking independence one year after total hip arthroplasty in patients with osteonecrosis of the femoral head.
results_summary: The study found a negative relationship between preoperative PNI levels and walking independence recovery, with low PNI (<42.2) independently associated with a 2.35-fold increased risk of losing walking independence. Results were robust, with significant heterogeneity observed across subgroups.
population_specificity: Patients with osteonecrosis of the femoral head undergoing primary unilateral total hip arthroplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Baduanjin and brisk walking on lower limb balance in elderly individuals.
results_summary: Brisk walking showed less improvement in balance parameters compared to Baduanjin, with the Baduanjin group demonstrating significantly better outcomes in reducing body sway and improving static balance. The control group (no exercise) performed the worst in balance tests.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals aged 65 to 79 (20 per group, 10 males and 10 females).
effective_dosage: Not specified (brisk walking regimen details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess kinematic changes in the knee joint during walking in patients with isolated PCL-deficiency (PCLD) and determine if walking-related joint instability occurs.
results_summary: The study found that patients with PCLD showed no joint instability during walking but exhibited reduced posterior tibial displacement and altered knee flexion angles compared to healthy controls. Adaptive gait changes were also observed in the uninvolved limb.
population_specificity: 35 healthy volunteers and 27 patients with isolated PCLD.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (walking at self-selected comfortable speed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the interobserver reliability of the Pirani scoring system for assessing clubfoot in walking-age children.
results_summary: The study found "fair" overall reliability (Cohen's kappa = 0.3) for Pirani scores in walking-age children, with registrars grading deformities as more severe than consultants. Subcomponents like head of talus showed moderate reliability, while others like medial crease had lower reliability.
population_specificity: Children >1 year old with idiopathic clubfoot (22 children, 35 feet).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify risk factors for reoperations following surgical treatments for developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) in children aged 1 to 3 years and derive treatment recommendations.
results_summary: The study found that 13% of patients underwent reoperations, with closed reduction associated with higher reoperation risk compared to open reduction, while pelvic osteotomy showed lower risk in patients aged 1.5 to 2 years. The findings support open reduction and pelvic osteotomy to reduce reoperation risk.
population_specificity: Children aged 1 to 3 years with unilateral DDH who underwent surgical procedures (closed reduction, open reduction, or osteotomy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the barriers and facilitators to physical activity, specifically walking, in stroke survivors with limited walking ability.
results_summary: The study identified barriers such as scarcity of services, societal views, and inclement weather, while facilitators included desired benefits of physical activity, rehabilitation services, and self-efficacy. The findings suggest improving access to rehabilitation and structured exercise programs could enhance participation.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors with limited walking ability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of Condoliase chemonucleolysis (CC) in nonambulatory patients with severe leg pain due to lumbar disc herniation (LDH).
results_summary: CC provided early pain relief, with significant reductions in leg pain scores (NRS-LP) in nonambulatory patients. By 3 months, 94% of initially nonambulatory patients regained ambulatory status.
population_specificity: 58 patients with conservative treatment-resistant LDH, including 16 nonambulatory due to severe leg pain.
study_duration: Follow-up at 1 week, 1 month, and 3 months post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of walking and bone joint exercise on enhancing bone remodeling biomarkers in menopausal women.
results_summary: Walking significantly increased estrogen levels, decreased RANKL and PTH levels, and improved bone mineral density (BMD) in menopausal women. No adverse effects were reported, and the results were statistically significant.
population_specificity: Menopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evidence for the effects of ankle-foot orthoses (AFOs) on improving walking in adults with calf muscle weakness due to slowly progressive neuromuscular disorders.
results_summary: Carbon AFOs may reduce walking energy cost and increase walking speed, while leather AFOs may also increase walking speed. Polypropylene and elastic AFOs showed little to no effect on walking speed. Evidence for other outcomes like perceived walking effort, balance, and AFO use was inconclusive.
population_specificity: Adults with calf muscle weakness due to slowly progressive neuromuscular disorders.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (intervention was AFO use, not a dosage-based treatment).
study_duration: Outcome measures were assessed during a single session, at delivery, or at three-week or three-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of percutaneous surgical techniques, specifically transverse osteotomy and distal screw fixation, in treating recurrent hallux valgus deformity and improving walking-related outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that percutaneous surgical techniques significantly improved clinical and radiographic outcomes for recurrent hallux valgus, effectively treating a wide range of deformity severities.
population_specificity: Individuals with recurrent hallux valgus deformity causing pain and walking difficulties.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the SBT-330 balance training device could improve walking and balance capabilities in stroke patients with impaired balance compared to conventional physical therapy.
results_summary: The study found that the SBT-330 device significantly improved balance and walking metrics (K-MBI, BBS, FAC) compared to conventional therapy, with no significant improvement in the TUG test for the control group. The experimental group showed clinically meaningful enhancements in functional outcomes.
population_specificity: 33 stroke patients with compromised balance.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of training with the SBT-330 device alongside standard physical therapy, 5 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore cilostazol's mechanisms and therapeutic applications for managing neuropathy and peripheral arterial disease (PAD) in diabetic patients, including its potential benefits for walking-related outcomes like claudication.
results_summary: The abstract highlights cilostazol's effectiveness in improving walking distances and blood flow in PAD patients with intermittent claudication, but does not directly report findings on walking itself.
population_specificity: Diabetic patients with neuropathy or peripheral arterial disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of remotely supervised tDCS combined with a telerehabilitation program on motor (balance and gait), cognitive, and participation outcomes in persons with multiple sclerosis (pwMS).
results_summary: The study found that telerehabilitation (TR) improved motor outcomes (balance and gait) in pwMS, with additional benefits in perceived walking difficulties and reduced anxiety when combined with active tDCS. The TR RS-AtDCS group showed significant improvements compared to other groups.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis (pwMS)
effective_dosage: 20 minutes of tDCS during the first week, alongside 45-minute TR sessions five times a week for 6 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) and moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) on 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure and cardiovascular outcomes in older adults with hypertension.
results_summary: The abstract describes the study protocol but does not report results, as it is a trial in progress.
population_specificity: Inactive older adults (60-80 years) with hypertension and no history of major adverse cardiovascular events.
effective_dosage: HIIT (3× week), MICT (3× week), or health education (1× week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare static, postural, dynamic, and clinical outcomes among different groups of CTEV patients treated with tenotomy or conservatively, relative to healthy controls.
results_summary: Bilateral CTEV patients treated with tenotomy showed static and dynamic values comparable to healthy controls, while bilateral patients had better dynamic values than unilateral patients. Significant differences were found in various postural, static, and dynamic measures, as well as in clinical scores like Pirani and FADI.
population_specificity: Patients with congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV), including bilateral and unilateral cases, treated with tenotomy or conservatively, and healthy controls.

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of mind-body exercise on physical ability, mental health, and quality of life in stroke patients.
results_summary: Mind-body exercise significantly improved balance ability and was found to be a low-intensity, high-safety supplement to conventional rehabilitation therapy, accelerating stroke recovery.
population_specificity: Stroke patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the long-term effects of metformin or intensive lifestyle intervention on 6-minute walk test performance in adults at high risk of type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found no sustained effect of the original interventions (lifestyle, metformin, or placebo) on 6-minute walk test performance after 20 years. However, the test was related to other measures of physical ability, such as physical activity and grip strength.
population_specificity: Adults at high risk of type 2 diabetes.
study_duration: 3-year intervention, followed by long-term follow-up (20 years total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of stretching exercise on improving walking performance and balance in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that stretching interventions improved balance and walking ability, with a meta-analysis of 6 studies showing increased gait speed compared to control groups. The results suggest potential benefits of stretching exercises for enhancing walking ability in older adults.
population_specificity: Older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how gait parameters change 24 hours after a CSF tap test (CSFTT) and after ventriculoperitoneal shunt surgery in patients with idiopathic normal pressure hydrocephalus (iNPH).
results_summary: The study found that self-selected walking speed and stride length significantly increased 24 hours after CSFTT, while cadence was not a suitable parameter for evaluating the effects of CSFTT and shunt surgery. Changes in balance-related gait parameters remained controversial.
population_specificity: Patients with idiopathic normal pressure hydrocephalus (iNPH).
effective_dosage: Varying amounts of CSF removed during the tap test (20-50 ml).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of non-invasive vagus nerve stimulation (nVNS) in managing motor symptoms, particularly Freezing of Gait (FOG), in Parkinson's disease (PD) patients.
results_summary: The study found that nVNS significantly improved FOG in PD patients but showed no significant effects on other motor symptoms like UPDRS scores, Time Up and Go, walking speed, or step length (except when measured in centimeters). No serious adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease (total n=217 across included studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of enhanced external counterpulsation (EECP) and individual shear rate therapy (ISRT) on peripheral artery function, walking distance, and quality of life in patients with lower extremity atherosclerotic disease (LEAD).
results_summary: EECP significantly improved brachial artery flow-mediated dilation, walking distance, blood flow, and quality of life, while ISRT increased blood flow in the anterior tibial artery. Both treatments reduced endothelin-1 and asymmetrical dimethylarginine levels, with EECP also lowering sVCAM-1.
population_specificity: 45 patients with lower extremity atherosclerotic disease (LEAD).
effective_dosage: 35 sessions of 45 minutes each for EECP and ISRT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if one-year adherence-supported high-intensity exercise (including walking/running) could lead to long-term routine exercise in outpatients with schizophrenia.
results_summary: The study found that one-year adherence-supported high-intensity training improved V̇O (oxygen uptake) in outpatients with schizophrenia, suggesting potential benefits of structured exercise.
population_specificity: Outpatients with schizophrenia (ICD-10: F20-29), 28 men and 20 women, mean age 35 ± 11 years.
effective_dosage: Aerobic interval training (4 × 4-min treadmill walking/running at ∼90% peak heart rate) and leg press maximal strength training (4 × 4 repetitions at ∼90% maximal strength) 2 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a combined exercise program (including walking) could improve functional fitness parameters in adults with intellectual disabilities.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in body mass, hip circumference, aerobic capacity, functional ability, muscular strength, balance, and flexibility after the 6-week intervention. The effects varied in magnitude but were statistically significant.
population_specificity: Adults with intellectual disabilities (mean age 44.5 ± 11.5 years).
effective_dosage: Three times a week (walking, dancing, and resistance training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of vascular photobiomodulation on pain interference with walking and other daily activities in post-COVID-19 patients with persistent headaches and orofacial pain.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in pain interference with walking (p=0.011) and other daily activities, though no significant difference was observed in headache impact on activities of daily living as measured by the HIT.
population_specificity: Post-COVID-19 patients with tension-type headache, orofacial pain, or both persisting for more than 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of physical exercise, including walking, on physical function, fatigue, and psychological outcomes in women with ovarian cancer.
results_summary: Preoperative walking expedited recovery, and adherence to ≥150 minutes of moderate-intensity exercise per week showed consistent benefits in physical function, fatigue, and psychological outcomes. However, significant heterogeneity in study protocols limited meta-analysis.
population_specificity: Women with ovarian cancer
effective_dosage: ≥150 minutes of moderate-intensity exercise per week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of disease-modifying treatments (DMTs) on infection rates in people with multiple sclerosis (MS), including the role of ambulatory status (walking aid use).
results_summary: The study found that patients requiring a walking aid had higher mild infection rates, but the abstract does not specifically evaluate the safety or efficacy of walking itself. Severe infections were more common in patients on fumarates, unrelated to walking.
population_specificity: Adult people with multiple sclerosis (MS) treated with natalizumab, S1P modulators, fumarates, or anti-CD20 medications for over two years.
study_duration: Over two years (treatment duration varied by DMT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare clinical outcomes and complication rates of different treatment modalities for toddler's fractures, particularly focusing on immobilization methods.
results_summary: The study found that traditional management (circumferential cast or posterior splint) had higher rates of skin breakdown compared to removable walking boot immobilization or no immobilization, with no significant risk of fracture displacement or healing failure across treatments. Current practices vary widely, indicating a need for updated guidelines.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (toddlers) with fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) on walking ability, cognitive function, and depression in patients with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that rTMS significantly improved walking ability, as measured by the TUGT and FOG-Q scores, in Parkinson's disease patients. It also enhanced cognitive function and alleviated depressive symptoms.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Samsung's Bot Fit wearable robot, specifically its assist mode and voice coach, on walking posture, stride length, and speed in older and younger adults.
results_summary: The study found that using Bot Fit's assist mode and voice coach increased pelvic movement, stride length, and walking speed compared to walking without the device. In young adults, stride length differences decreased under certain assist and voice coach conditions.
population_specificity: Older and younger adults (58 total participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of Naturagen® 4 Joint (a collagen-based supplement) on osteoarthritis-related pain, quality of life, and physical functioning.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in pain, quality of life, and some functional tests (BBS and 6MWT) after eight weeks of collagen supplementation, though no significant differences were observed in TUG, 5STS, and SCT tests.
population_specificity: 31 patients (8 males, 23 females; mean age 53.5±9.1 years) with Grade 2-3 osteoarthritis per Kellgren-Lawrence classification.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize consumer perspectives on the benefits, limitations, and expectations of FES and robotic exoskeleton technologies for restoring walking in individuals with spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The study found that FES and robotic exoskeletons offer multifaceted benefits, including improved mobility and psychological gains like increased independence, but face limitations related to accessibility, cost, and usability. Consumer expectations highlighted the need for more personalized, affordable, and adaptable solutions.
population_specificity: Persons with spinal cord injury, their caregivers, medical service providers, researchers, and technology developers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether cognitive-motor dual-task training (CMDT) is more effective than conventional single-task training for improving balance and gait in hemiplegic stroke patients.
results_summary: CMDT showed potential benefits for static balance (Berg Balance Scale) but did not significantly affect dynamic balance (Time Up and Go test) or single-task walking speed. The evidence was of low quality, with heterogeneity and potential biases noted.
population_specificity: Hemiplegic stroke patients (n=751 across 17 RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop physical activity recommendations, including walking, for patients undergoing metabolic and bariatric surgery to improve outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that walking and other physical activities, when progressively increased and structured, can improve postoperative outcomes for MBS patients, with specific recommendations for timing and intensity.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS).
effective_dosage: 150-300 minutes of accumulated moderate-intensity cardiovascular exercise/week, including walking.
study_duration: Recommendations span from pre-surgery to long-term postoperative monitoring.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effectiveness of foot exercises and minimalist shoes in modifying foot muscle sizes, strength, and biomechanical outcomes during locomotion.
results_summary: Minimalist shoes increased toe strength (toes 2-5), and foot exercises reduced medial longitudinal arch motion during running. The evidence was low to very low certainty due to limited studies and high bias, but interventions occasionally modified walking and running biomechanics.
population_specificity: 1399 participants across 28 trials (specific demographics not detailed).
study_duration: Intervention duration of four weeks or more.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess current EMG practices, associated knowledge, and barriers to EMG usage in UK and European clinical gait labs.
results_summary: EMG was used for assessing muscle activation timings, spasticity, and co-contraction, often as a confirmatory tool. Challenges included justifying effort, distinguishing deviations from the norm, data quality, and patient feasibility.
population_specificity: Professionals from 13 gait labs across the UK and wider Europe, including physiotherapists, clinical scientists, and biomedical engineers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of a physical activity intervention based on King's Attainment Theory in improving body composition, physical activity levels, and motivational variables in physically inactive emerging adults.
results_summary: The intervention significantly improved body composition (reduced visceral fat area, body fat mass, and body fat percentage), increased physical activity levels (vigorous, moderate, walking, and total activity), and enhanced motivational variables (introjected motivation and self-efficacy) compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Emerging adults with physical inactivity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic effects of Baduanjin exercise with conventional pulmonary rehabilitation (CPR) in patients with COPD, implemented by rural doctors.
results_summary: Both Baduanjin and CPR groups showed significant improvements in health status, dyspnoea, walking distance, and mental health scores compared to the control group, with no adverse events reported. The effects of Baduanjin were similar to CPR.
population_specificity: 472 COPD patients from 18 rural village clinics.
effective_dosage: Six months of Baduanjin training (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of two non-vital tooth whitening techniques, In-office and Walking Bleach, using 35% hydrogen peroxide to determine which achieves greater tooth color improvement.
results_summary: Both techniques improved tooth color, with the In-office method showing slightly greater whitening efficacy and faster results. Significant differences favoring the In-office method were observed after the first bleaching and at one-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Fifty non-vital anterior teeth with discoloration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve clinical skills in observational gait analysis for paediatricians and provide a structured approach to diagnosing walking-related complaints.
results_summary: The review highlights advances in understanding normal gait and interpreting gait deviations, enhancing observational gait analysis quality while defining its limitations. It also discusses causes of limps and rotational deformities, offering tools to improve observational analysis.
population_specificity: Practising paediatricians and paediatric patients with walking or limb alignment complaints.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the efficacy, challenges, and future prospects of sacroiliac joint reduction therapy for improving gait balance and reducing lumbosacral pain.
results_summary: The study found that sacroiliac joint reduction therapy improved gait parameters like stride length, speed, and cycle uniformity, enhancing walking stability and reducing fall risk. However, challenges such as lack of standardized diagnostic criteria and need for further long-term studies were noted.
population_specificity: Individuals with lumbosacral pain and gait balance disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify metastatic breast cancer patients' preferences for exercise programs, including walking, and associate these preferences with patient characteristics.
results_summary: The study identified four distinct classes of patients with different exercise preferences, including active walking (13%) and recreational walking (10%). Walking preferences were associated with fewer bone metastases and comorbidities.
population_specificity: Metastatic breast cancer patients (n=409) from a multinational survey.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the timing of high-intensity gait training post-spinal cord injury (SCI) affects walking performance, hypothesizing that early intervention yields the greatest improvements.
results_summary: The study compares the efficacy of high-intensity gait training initiated at different time intervals post-SCI (<60 days, 3 months, 6 months) versus standard of care, with primary outcomes focusing on gait speed and walking endurance. Secondary outcomes include step count, strength, and quality of life, assessed over 12 months post-SCI.
population_specificity: 108 participants with acute, traumatic spinal cord injury.
study_duration: Intervention duration not specified; follow-up assessments at 3, 6, 9, and 12 months post-SCI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate the prevalence of falls in older adults with type 2 diabetes (T2D) and identify associated risk factors, including walking-related factors.
results_summary: The study found a 19.7% fall prevalence rate among T2D patients, with factors like longer walking time, depression, and cognitive impairment significantly increasing fall risk. Depression was particularly impactful, with each additional unit on the depression score raising fall risk by 11.9%.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 73.9 years) with type 2 diabetes recruited from a community-based diabetes specialist clinic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of exercise interventions, including walking, on mobility, postural control, and falls in older adults with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: Aerobic exercise, multicomponent exercise, and cognitive-motor training significantly improved gait speed and functional performance in older adults with MCI, but effects on postural control and fall risk were inconclusive.
population_specificity: Older adults with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and efficacy of paclitaxel-coated balloon (PCB) treatment versus conventional balloon angioplasty for diabetic subpatellar artery disease, focusing on outcomes like restenosis rates and walking impairment.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in primary patency rates at 6 months but lower restenosis rates and better walking impairment improvement in the PCB group at 12 months. Adverse events were similar between groups.
population_specificity: 140 diabetic patients with subknee arterial disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of exercise therapy, including walking, on fatigue, physical functioning, and other outcomes in adults with chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) compared to other interventions or controls.
results_summary: Exercise therapy, including walking, probably reduces fatigue and may improve physical functioning and sleep in adults with CFS compared to passive controls, but the long-term effects and safety remain uncertain. Compared to cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) or adaptive pacing, exercise therapy showed little to no difference in fatigue reduction or other outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults with a primary diagnosis of CFS, based on various diagnostic criteria, who were able to participate in exercise therapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (mixed levels of intensity from very low to rigorous aerobic exercise).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between pain and gait characteristics (e.g., gait speed, cadence, stride length) in older people to understand how pain impacts mobility and fall risk.
results_summary: Older people with pain exhibited slower gait speed compared to those without pain, with a small but statistically significant effect size. No significant differences were found in cadence, stride length, or double-limb support time.
population_specificity: People aged 60 years and over with and without pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of cork and silicone insoles on balance and postural stability in the elderly.
results_summary: Cork insoles significantly improved balance, maximum plantar pressure, and functional mobility compared to silicone insoles. Both materials enhanced some balance parameters, but cork was more effective in key outcomes.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals at the Istanbul Barinyurt Elderly Care Center (n=24).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current knowledge on how increased fear of falling (FOF) leads to falls in patients undergoing hemodialysis (HD).
results_summary: Patients undergoing HD exhibit heightened FOF compared to the general elderly population, which correlates with reduced physical activity and function. Increased FOF may interact with physical inactivity and frailty, affecting lower limb muscle activity during walking and elevating fall risk.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing hemodialysis (HD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare walking performance between individuals with and without asymptomatic peripheral artery disease (PAD) using two walking tests (6MWT and ISWT) and to investigate correlations between ABI-TBI and walking distance.
results_summary: Individuals with asymptomatic PAD showed no difference in 6MWT performance but exhibited significantly shorter distances in ISWT compared to those without PAD. A positive correlation was found between right leg TBI and ISWD.
population_specificity: 76 participants (38 with asymptomatic PAD and 38 without PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish standardized clinical practice guidelines for gait analysis to improve diagnosis, intervention planning, and patient outcomes in various populations.
results_summary: The study outlined technical and procedural recommendations for gait analysis, including data recording, staff management, and quality assurance, to enhance standardization and improve clinical practices and research conditions in central Europe.
population_specificity: Various patient populations with gait abnormalities (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if mechanically assisted walking with body weight support improves independent walking and walking ability in non-ambulatory individuals after stroke compared to usual walking training, and whether these benefits persist long-term.
results_summary: Mechanically assisted walking with body weight support resulted in more independent walking and better walking ability in the short term, with benefits maintained in the longer term, without detriment to walking speed.
population_specificity: Non-ambulatory adults ≤ 12 weeks after stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a 10-week mobile app-based walking intervention outside school hours improved physical activity, body composition, physical fitness, and psychological state in overweight and obese adolescents.
results_summary: The intervention showed no significant improvements in body composition, physical fitness, or psychological state compared to the control group. Some minor physical improvements were noted in the experimental group, but these were not statistically significant when compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese adolescents aged 12-16 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (step tracker mobile app used for walking in free time).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) and repetitive spinal magnetic stimulation (rSMS) is more effective than rTMS alone in improving axial and other motor disabilities in Parkinson's disease (PD).
results_summary: The study found that combining rTMS and rSMS significantly improved motor and axial symptoms in PD patients compared to rTMS alone, with notable improvements in MDS-UPDRS scores and walking speed, though some effects diminished after one month.
population_specificity: 42 PD patients with axial symptoms.
effective_dosage: Group I received active rTMS (2000 pulses; 20 Hz; 80% resting motor threshold) + active rSMS (1500 pulses; 10 Hz; 50% of maximal stimulator output); Group II received active rTMS + sham rSMS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the influence of core training integrated with respiratory therapy on walking function (stability and endurance) in elderly stable COPD patients.
results_summary: The study will evaluate the effects of combined core training and respiratory therapy on walking function, measured by the 6-minute walk test and secondary outcomes like balance, pulmonary function, and quality of life. Results are pending as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: Elderly patients diagnosed with stable chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: To determine whether ESWT can safely and positively influence specific ADL activities in people with SCI and spasticity, measured by Goal Attainment Scaling (GAS).
results_summary: 28 of 33 GAS items improved after ESWT, with effects generally maintained during follow-up. Secondary outcome measures varied, and no serious adverse events occurred.
population_specificity: 11 participants with SCI, aged >18 years, with hindering spasticity in upper or lower limbs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the acceptability of a community walking and home-based circuit training program for people with intermittent claudication by gathering participants' opinions and experiences.
results_summary: The program was well received by completers, with some reporting improvements in physical activity and symptoms, though barriers like pain management and guidance were noted. Participants generally recommended the program, but further improvements were suggested.
population_specificity: People with intermittent claudication (IC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of combined robot-assisted gait training with traditional balance training versus traditional balance training alone on balance and fear of falling in stroke patients.
results_summary: Combined training improved balance (EncephaLog sways, stand-up/sit-down times, Berg Balance Scale) and reduced fear of falling (International Fall Efficacy Scale) more effectively than traditional training alone, while traditional training showed better improvement in limb impairment (Fugl-Meyer Assessment-Lower Extremity).
population_specificity: Patients with subacute and chronic stroke

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate and categorize health problems in children with profound intellectual and multiple disabilities (PIMD), focusing on conditions like epilepsy, respiratory infections, and feeding difficulties.
results_summary: The study identified common health problems in children with PIMD, including epilepsy, respiratory infections, feeding difficulties, GERD, scoliosis, and visual impairment, but did not specifically address Walking.
population_specificity: Children with profound intellectual and multiple disabilities (PIMD), defined by severe intellectual disability (IQ/DQ < 35 or developmental age < 24 months) and severe/profound motor impairment (non-ambulatory/not walking without support).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of daridorexant on auditory awakening threshold, postural stability, and cognitive function during the night following evening administration.
results_summary: Daridorexant showed no significant differences in auditory awakening threshold compared to placebo, marginally increased body sway (22%), and had minimal, clinically insignificant effects on functional mobility and cognitive function. Effects on body sway were driven by nonelderly adults, with elderly subjects showing results similar to placebo.
population_specificity: 36 healthy male and female nonelderly adults and elderly subjects (1:1 sex/age ratio).
effective_dosage: 25 mg and 50 mg, administered at bedtime.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare clinical outcomes and gait function changes between patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty (TKA) and unicompartmental knee arthroplasty (UKA).
results_summary: The study found that UKA showed superior gait recovery in multiple parameters compared to TKA, though clinical scores did not significantly differ between the two groups at one year post-surgery. Seven out of ten studies reported better gait improvements for UKA, including walking speed, step length, and knee joint range of motion.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent TKA (171) or UKA (148).
study_duration: Follow-up assessments up to 1 year post-operation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the prevalence, clinical implications, diagnostic methods, and treatment interventions for sarcopenia in patients with interstitial lung disease (ILD).
results_summary: The study found that sarcopenia is common in ILD patients (affecting nearly one-third) and is associated with adverse outcomes and increased mortality risk. Validated screening tools like the SARC-F questionnaire and grip strength dynamometry were highlighted, while medical imaging techniques remain uncertain for diagnosis. Multidimensional interventions such as pulmonary rehabilitation were noted as beneficial.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic forms of interstitial lung disease (ILD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility of a broad test battery to evaluate physical functioning and frailty in a non-geriatric community-based population experiencing homelessness and addiction.
results_summary: The study demonstrated high feasibility of the test battery, with 100% completion for most outcomes, though a ceiling effect was detected for the Short Physical Performance Battery. An optimized test battery was proposed based on findings.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-65 experiencing homelessness and addiction, attending an open-access day-service center.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of a cardiovascular rehabilitation (CR) programme versus usual care on walking capacity and quality of life in patients who underwent lower limb revascularisation for peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study found that supervised exercise training, including intermittent treadmill walking, improved walking capacity in PAD patients post-revascularisation, with primary outcomes measured by 6-minute walk distance and secondary outcomes including pain-free walking distance and cardiorespiratory fitness.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent lower limb revascularisation for PAD in the previous 12 months.
effective_dosage: Two supervised exercise sessions per week for 6 weeks, primarily consisting of intermittent treadmill walking at moderate intensity, plus home-based walking advice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the physical activity levels of men with metastatic prostate cancer to guidelines and examine associations with physical fitness, including walking performance.
results_summary: The study found that only 29% of participants met aerobic physical activity guidelines, but higher moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) was associated with better aerobic capacity and walking performance. No significant association was found between MVPA and maximal strength.
population_specificity: Men with metastatic prostate cancer on androgen deprivation therapy (ADT).
study_duration: Not specified (cross-sectional analysis of baseline data)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the association between vitamin D status and energy metabolism, including walking energy expenditure, in young, healthy, non-obese adults.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in walking energy expenditure or other metabolic measures based on vitamin D status, with weak correlations between vitamin D and certain lipid markers.
population_specificity: Sixty-nine healthy, non-obese adults (mean age = 22.8 years, mean BMI = 20.7 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify digital-motor outcomes for SPG7 spastic ataxia that reflect patient-relevant health aspects, are suitable for multicenter settings, and assess mobility during uninstructed walking.
results_summary: The study identified 18 gait measures with moderate effect sizes for discriminating SPG7 patients from controls, even in mild disease stages, and found correlations with functional mobility and disease severity measures. These outcomes demonstrated multicenter applicability and potential for future trials.
population_specificity: 65 patients with SPG7 spastic ataxia and 50 healthy controls across 7 centers in 6 countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of therapeutic exercise interventions with virtual reality (VR) training on balance and walking in individuals with chronic stroke, compared to control groups without VR.
results_summary: VR training had a large effect on balance and a moderate effect on walking in chronic stroke patients, with no serious side effects reported. The impact on walking was lower than on balance, and the study found no significant relationship between VR intervention content, control group type, or VR immersion level and outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18+ with a chronic stroke diagnosis (≥6 months post-stroke) who could walk without assistance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of physical activity (PA) counseling, including walking, on reducing suicidal ideation in primary care patients with mental health problems.
results_summary: The study found that PA counseling led to significant increases in walking and other physical activities, along with reductions in depressive and anxiety symptoms, and a drop in suicidal ideation prevalence from 8.5% to 9% post-intervention.
population_specificity: Primary care patients with mental health problems in Uganda (n=11, median age=52 years).
effective_dosage: Once weekly group PA counseling for 8 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the psychometric properties of performance-based tests (PBTs), including walking, in fibromyalgia patients to determine their reliability, validity, and responsiveness.
results_summary: The 6-minute walking test was the most frequently assessed PBT, with moderate quality evidence for reliability and very good methodological quality for validity. However, overall methodological quality for reliability was doubtful, and construct validity and responsiveness were seldom determined.
population_specificity: Fibromyalgia patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the prevalence and outcomes of supervised exercise and education in patients with established and early-stage knee osteoarthritis (KOA).
results_summary: Patients with early-stage KOA showed similar improvements in pain, quality of life, walking speed, and chair-stand tests compared to those with established KOA, supporting supervised exercise and education as an effective management strategy for early-stage KOA.
population_specificity: Patients with established KOA, early-stage KOA, or potential early-stage KOA from the GLA:D® program in Denmark.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between fall risk-increasing drugs (FRIDs) and the incidence of total, injurious, and recurrent falls in generally healthy, community-dwelling older adults.
results_summary: The study found that baseline use of FRIDs, especially multiple FRIDs, was significantly associated with increased incidence rates of total, injurious, and recurrent falls over a 3-year follow-up period. The associations were most pronounced among users of multiple FRIDs.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults aged ≥70 years without major diseases at baseline.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on medication use, not walking dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the research status of aquatic therapy (AT) for improving gross motor function, cardiopulmonary function, and daily living abilities in patients with spastic cerebral palsy (CP).
results_summary: AT significantly improved gross motor ability, walking efficiency, muscle strength, daily activities, and quality of life in patients with spastic CP. Functional improvements were correlated with child age, CP type, and gross motor function classification system grade.
population_specificity: Patients with spastic cerebral palsy (CP).
effective_dosage: Five weekly interventions (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a walking program based on the COM-B Behavior Change Model could improve self-management, mental health, quality of life, and seizure frequency in individuals with epilepsy.
results_summary: The walking program significantly increased self-management, reduced anxiety, stress, and depression, improved quality of life, and decreased seizure frequency in the intervention group, with no significant changes in the control group.
population_specificity: Individuals with epilepsy (n=78, intervention group n=38, control group n=40).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to expand the clinical phenotype of SETD5-related disorder by describing neurological, psychiatric, EEG, and brain MRI data in 28 previously unreported patients.
results_summary: The study found that gait abnormalities, including tip-toe or unsteady walking, were present in 35.7% of patients with SETD5-related disorder, along with other neurological symptoms like hypotonia and hyperkinetic movement disorders.
population_specificity: 28 patients with SETD5-related disorder, characterized by intellectual disability, autism, and facial dysmorphisms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of two respiratory training programs, combined with individualized flexibility, strengthening, and cardiovascular exercise programs, on physiologic, activity, and societal participation outcomes in chronic stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study will evaluate the impact of respiratory strength training versus respiratory relaxation training on outcomes such as maximal respiratory pressure, walking endurance, and community walking, with results anticipated in Fall 2026.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults with chronic stroke (n=80).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the use of wearable sensors and machine learning to estimate biomechanical characteristics related to balance during walking.
results_summary: Most studies demonstrated strong accuracy in estimating biomechanical characteristics (e.g., center of pressure and center of mass motion) using wearable sensors and neural network models, with RMSE <15% and correlation coefficients >0.85. The review highlighted the potential for wearable technology to assess balance outside laboratory settings.
population_specificity: Clinical populations with balance deficits (specific conditions not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether biofeedback (BFB) training targeting specific gait phases (stance phase or single stance phase) could restore gait function in hemiparetic stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found that BFB training significantly improved clinical scores in both patient groups, with stance phase training showing more pronounced effects on the unaffected limb. However, single stance phase training did not significantly alter the target parameter in either limb.
population_specificity: 40 hemiparetic patients in the subacute stage of stroke and 20 healthy controls.
effective_dosage: 8 to 11 training sessions (specific frequency not detailed).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but implied over several sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how Brazilian physical therapists prescribe aerobic exercise (primarily walking) for individuals after stroke and identify perceived barriers in clinical rehabilitation.
results_summary: Overground walking was the most prescribed aerobic exercise (89%), typically at moderate intensity (40%-59% of heart rate reserve) for 44 ± 17 minutes, twice a week. Cognitive dysfunction in stroke patients was the most cited barrier (58%).
population_specificity: Brazilian physical therapists who had treated at least one individual after stroke in the last 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the effects of interval walking exercise (IWE) using a wearable robot (Bot Fit) on older adults, focusing on pelvic movement, muscle power, and waist-to-hip ratio.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in pelvic tilt and rotation ranges, increased rectus abdominis muscle power, and reduced waist-to-hip ratio in the experimental group using Bot Fit after six weeks. The control group showed no such significant changes.
population_specificity: Older adults (experimental group n=10, control group n=12).
effective_dosage: Three times a week for six weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether walking backward could improve craniovertebral angle, proprioception, balance, and plantar pressure in individuals with forward head posture.
results_summary: The study found that walking backward significantly improved craniovertebral angle, neck proprioception, balance, and plantar pressure distribution in participants with forward head posture. The intervention group showed statistically significant improvements compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 46 female students (aged 22.89 ± 2.31 years) with forward head posture.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of combined resistance and balance training (RBT) versus resistance training (RT) alone and no exercise on physical function in older adults.
results_summary: RBT significantly improved dynamic balance, walking speed, muscle strength, and spirometry compared to no exercise, with additional benefits over RT in balance and lower limb strength. Only RBT improved normal walking speed.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults aged 60-74 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of various fall prevention interventions, including walking, for community-dwelling older adults.
results_summary: The study found no moderate certainty evidence for the benefit of walking in preventing falls among older adults. Walking was not among the interventions with demonstrated efficacy.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults aged 65 years or older.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-pressure-processed (HPP) rice intake during interval walking training (IWT) improved glycemic control and enhanced methylation of the NFKB2 gene in hyperglycemic older adults.
results_summary: HPP rice intake during IWT led to improved glycemic control, including reduced variability in fasting blood glucose and decreased post-breakfast glucose levels, with changes correlated to NFKB2 gene methylation. The effects were statistically significant but modest in magnitude.
population_specificity: Hyperglycemic older adults (~70 years) who had already performed IWT for ≥6 months.
effective_dosage: 75 g dry weight of HPP rice at breakfast and dinner.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a scaled-up citywide intervention could promote physical activity, including walking, among middle-aged and older adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant increase in walking activity (-1.8% points [-3.6, 0.1]) after two years of intervention, despite overall increases in physical activity, particularly muscle-strengthening activities.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and older adults (40-79 years) in Unnan City, Japan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of specific improvements to urban green spaces, including walking paths, on physical activity, mental health, and educational outcomes, as well as their cost-effectiveness.
results_summary: Interventions targeting walking paths or overall greenery showed mixed impacts on physical activity, while mental health and educational outcomes were understudied. Cost-effectiveness analysis suggested small improvements could make interventions viable, but evidence limitations were noted.
population_specificity: Urban populations living near green spaces (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare surgical insult, mortality, complications, and walking recovery after one year in elderly patients (>65 years) treated with cannulated screws or hemiarthroplasty for non-displaced femoral neck fractures.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in walking recovery between the two treatments, with 50.45% of osteosynthesis patients and 45% of hemiarthroplasty patients returning to pre-fracture walking ability. There were also no differences in worsening walking status between the groups.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (>65 years) with non-displaced femoral neck fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the outcomes and safety of two types of one-way valves (Zephyr EBVs and Spiration SVS) for endoscopic lung volume reduction in patients with severe lung emphysema, including their impact on walking distance (6MWD).
results_summary: Both valve types showed significant improvements in lung function and quality of life, with no significant differences in outcomes between them. The 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) improved comparably in both groups, indicating similar efficacy for enhancing walking capacity.
population_specificity: Patients with severe lung emphysema from three German centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between corticospinal tract (CST) integrity and clinical scores of standing balance and walking independence poststroke.
results_summary: The study found no significant correlation between CST integrity and standing balance or walking independence in the sub-acute phase, with weak prognostic value for walking at 6 months.
population_specificity: Poststroke individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a community-based structured exercise program compared to usual care in improving physical, functional, and psychological outcomes for ambulatory individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: The exercise group showed significant improvements in walking capacity (6-minute walk test), balance (Berg Balance Scale), lower extremity strength (30-second sit-to-stand), and flexibility (sit and reach test) compared to the usual care group. No significant changes were observed in psychological or quality-of-life measures.
population_specificity: Ambulatory individuals with chronic, motor incomplete spinal cord injury (SCI) who could walk more than 10 meters.
effective_dosage: A supervised 20-session program (flexibility, aerobic, and strengthening exercises) over 8 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of breakfast timing and a 20-minute post-breakfast walk on postprandial glycaemia in adults with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Delaying breakfast to mid-morning or midday reduced postprandial glycaemia compared to an early breakfast. A 20-minute post-meal walk had a small effect on lowering glycaemia when breakfast was early or midday but no effect when breakfast was mid-morning.
population_specificity: Eleven adults with type 2 diabetes (average age 57 ± 7 years, HbA1c 7.4 ± 1%).
study_duration: Six weeks (three 4-day conditions with a second 4-day intervention for walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the biomechanical aspects of the 5-repetition sit-to-stand (5STS) performance and compare its ability, along with muscle power equations, to discriminate older women with different physical function levels.
results_summary: The study found that peak concentric muscle power was highest in the first 5STS repetition and declined significantly. Biomechanical aspects of 5STS were associated with physical performance, but muscle power equations were not.
population_specificity: Older women from the community.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an information campaign targeting patients and healthcare professionals to optimize referral timing for knee and/or hip osteoarthritis (KHOA) care.
results_summary: The study protocol describes the design of an information campaign and a cluster RCT to assess its impact on healthcare utilization, including referral rates to secondary care, quality of care, beliefs about treatment, physical activity, and self-management behavior. Results are not yet available as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: Dutch-speaking patients aged 50-75 years with early-stage KHOA, without joint replacement or significant walking impairment, registered in general practices.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review slow gait speed measurement practices in diagnosing motoric cognitive risk (MCR) syndrome to identify critical constructs for improving diagnostic accuracy.
results_summary: The study found significant heterogeneity in slow gait speed measurement methods across MCR studies, including variations in tools, protocols, and cutoff values. Commonly used methods included manual stopwatches, 4-meter walking tests with 2-meter buffers, and averaging 2 tests, with a need for cohort-specific cutoff values.
population_specificity: Individuals with motoric cognitive risk (MCR) syndrome in clinical and community settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of web-based pulmonary telerehabilitation (WBPTR) in improving walking and other health outcomes for COPD patients compared to traditional care.
results_summary: WBPTR led to a small increase in daily step count but did not meet clinically meaningful thresholds. No significant improvements were observed in the six-minute walking test, health-related quality of life, or dyspnoea-related health status.
population_specificity: Participants with moderate to severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a technology-based dog-walking intervention could increase daily physical activity among dog owners in the general community.
results_summary: The study found no significant within- or between-group differences in physical activity levels, with both groups already averaging over 10,500 steps/day at baseline. Sedentary time increased post-intervention and at 6-month follow-up for both groups.
population_specificity: Dog owners in Sydney, Australia (mean age ~42-43 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the circumstances of falls in older inpatients and investigate factors influencing serious fall injuries, including activities like walking.
results_summary: Walking or rehabilitating was associated with a higher risk of serious fall injuries (aOR = 3.039) compared to lying. The study did not evaluate walking as a therapeutic intervention but as a risk factor for falls.
population_specificity: Older inpatients (5048 patients, 5143 fall incidents) in 67 hospitals in Hunan, China.
study_duration: Data collected from January 2019 to December 2022 (retrospective analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify prognostic risk factors, including walking history, that influence physical therapy outcomes for chronic low back pain (CLBP).
results_summary: The study found that a history of jogging/walking was among the top predictive variables for outcomes in CLBP treatment, suggesting its potential role in influencing recovery. Other significant factors included functional status scores, age, obesity, and previous treatments.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic low back pain receiving physical therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a group-based physical activity program delivered in Black churches to improve physical function among older Black adults with physical function limitations.
results_summary: The study compares a 24-week group-based intervention (including walking, strength, balance, and stretching) with a self-guided program, assessing physical function change as the primary outcome. Secondary outcomes include changes in moderate-to-vigorous physical activity, social support, self-efficacy, quality of life, and self-reported physical function.
population_specificity: Black adults aged ≥ 40 years with physical function limitations (SPPB score ≤ 9).
effective_dosage: Not specified (structured PA sessions weekly for the intervention arm).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of mind-body exercise on walking function in children with cerebral palsy (CP).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no statistically significant beneficial effects of mind-body exercise on walking function in children with CP (SMD = -0.23, P = 0.58). However, it did improve balance function (SMD = 0.48, P = 0.006).
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy (CP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the impact of kinematic alignment (KA) versus mechanical alignment (MA) in total knee arthroplasty (TKA) on plantar pressure distribution during walking gait.
results_summary: KA-TKA showed better clinical outcomes (Oxford Knee Scores) and restored a more physiologic plantar pressure distribution compared to MA-TKA, which exhibited greater medial pressure in the forefoot and more lateral pressure in the rearfoot. No significant differences were found between KA-TKA and the contralateral native knee.
population_specificity: Thirty-seven patients who underwent TKA (19 KA-TKA, 18 MA-TKA), each with a native contralateral knee.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and participant engagement of a virtual group walking intervention (Virtual PACE-Life) for adults with schizophrenia.
results_summary: Participants viewed the virtual walking program positively but found it challenging and inadequate for social interaction. Completers preferred virtual programs, while non-completers preferred in-person programs, with attendance barriers differing between groups.
population_specificity: Adults with schizophrenia (n=15).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of moderate-intensity walking versus Baduanjin exercise in improving cardiac function and alleviating anxiety and depression symptoms in post-PCI AMI patients.
results_summary: The control group (moderate-intensity walking) showed improvements in cardiac function (left ventricular ejection fraction), physical function (6-minute walk test), and mental state (Hamilton Anxiety and Depression Scales), though these improvements were generally less pronounced than in the Baduanjin group. Walking was associated with statistically significant but modest benefits in some outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with acute myocardial infarction (AMI) who underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) (n=120).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal implant materials (biodegradable and non-biodegradable) for stabilizing transverse femoral shaft fractures during the walking cycle.
results_summary: The study found that magnesium alloy was superior among biodegradable materials, while titanium alloy was preferred among non-biodegradable options for femoral stabilization during walking. Magnesium alloy was recommended due to its advantages over non-degradable alternatives.
population_specificity: Patients with transverse femoral shaft fractures requiring surgical intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether multimodal prehabilitation, including walking, reduces postoperative complications and improves functional recovery in frail elderly patients undergoing gastric cancer surgery.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in the primary outcome (30-day CCI) but noted a reduction in severe complications and improved perioperative functional walking capacity (6MWD) in the intervention group.
population_specificity: Frail elderly patients (aged 65+, Fried Frailty Index ≥2) scheduled for gastric cancer surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and evaluate functional capacity assessment tools, including walking tests, for preoperative risk stratification in elective noncardiac surgery.
results_summary: Field walking tests were among the most studied performance-based tools (58 studies, 9393 patients), with most evidence focusing on predictive validity for cardiorespiratory complications, though gaps in reliability and pragmatic qualities were noted.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing elective noncardiac surgery, with older adults (≥65 years) well-represented but limited data for those with obesity, lower-limb arthritis, or disability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the hemodynamic effects of aerobic exercise (brisk walking and cycling) with isometric handgrip exercise in reducing blood pressure in older hypertensive participants.
results_summary: Aerobic exercise (including brisk walking) significantly reduced office and ambulatory systolic blood pressure, comparable to isometric handgrip exercise, but was less effective in reducing diastolic blood pressure.
population_specificity: Older hypertensive participants (age ≥60; mean age 69 years)
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of brisk walking and cycling at moderate intensity, thrice weekly

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of a multistrain probiotic on postural imbalance in patients with knee osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of the probiotic on postural imbalance in OA patients.
population_specificity: 147 patients aged 64-75 years with knee OA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 28 consecutive days of remote ischaemic preconditioning (RIPC) improved intermittent claudication symptoms compared with a sham intervention.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in maximum walking distance, intermittent claudication distance, or time to relief from claudication with RIPC compared to sham treatment. Changes in health-related quality of life were also not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 41 men with stable intermittent claudication (Fontaine stage IIa or IIb), aged 64.9 ± 7.4 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention was RIPC or sham for 28 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of plaster casts, crutches, and walking boots in treating traumatic bone marrow edema of the talus.
results_summary: Crutches (non-weight-bearing) showed better clinical outcomes than plaster casts, with higher AOFAS scores and greater pain reduction (VAS scores). Walking boots were also studied but not directly compared in efficacy to crutches.
population_specificity: 70 patients with traumatic bone marrow edema of the talus.
effective_dosage: Not specified (interventions: plaster cast, crutches, walking boot).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the prevalence and impact of frailty in people with multiple sclerosis (MS), including its association with walking performance and other clinical outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that frailty is highly prevalent in MS and is associated with reduced walking performance, among other adverse outcomes like lower sleep quality, fatigue, and falls. Higher disability levels and disease duration were commonly linked to frailty.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (pwMS), with mean participant ages ranging from 41.2 to 58.6 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether persons with progressive MS (PwPMS) could synchronize their steps to auditory cues (music and metronomes) and adapt their gait to varying tempi.
results_summary: Both PwPMS and healthy controls could synchronize steps to auditory cues, with better consistency for metronomes and healthy controls. PwPMS struggled with gait speed adaptation at higher tempi and showed more variable inter-step intervals with metronomes. Dynamic balance significantly affected synchronization consistency.
population_specificity: Persons with progressive multiple sclerosis (PwPMS) and healthy controls (HCs).
effective_dosage: Five tempi conditions (-8%, -4%, 0%, 4%, 8% relative to baseline).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of TENS therapy on reducing pain, fatigue, and gait impairment in individuals with long-COVID experiencing fibromyalgia-like symptoms.
results_summary: High-dose TENS therapy significantly reduced functional interference from pain and improved gait parameters (stride time, cadence, double-support phase) compared to baseline. A subgroup meeting fibromyalgia criteria also showed reduced fatigue interference.
population_specificity: Twenty-five individuals with long-COVID experiencing fibromyalgia-like symptoms.
effective_dosage: Daily 3-5 hours of TENS therapy (high dose for intervention group, low dose for placebo group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if combining transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) with conventional exercise therapy enhances balance and mobility in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) compared to exercise alone.
results_summary: The study found that combining tDCS with exercise led to small but significant improvements in balance and walking speed in PwMS, lasting up to six months post-intervention. No benefits were observed for fatigue, falls, or quality of life.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (mean age 54, mean EDSS 3.5).
effective_dosage: 12 sessions of tDCS (2mA, bipolar) for 20 minutes, twice a week for six weeks.
study_duration: Six weeks of intervention with follow-up assessments at six months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of exercise, specifically walking, on anxiety symptoms in pregnant women with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).
results_summary: The study found a trend of self-selected pace walking reducing anxiety scores (BAI), though the results were not statistically significant. Brisk walking (30-45 min) three times per week was suggested to potentially improve anxiety states in women with GDM.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).
effective_dosage: Brisk walking for 30-45 minutes, three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic benefits of theta burst stimulation (iTBS and cTBS) on lower-limb motor dysfunction and balance recovery in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found that iTBS significantly improved balance function (Berg Balance Scale scores) but did not significantly enhance lower-limb motor function, walking performance, mobility, or activities of daily living. CRB-iTBS was more effective than LE M1-iTBS for balance improvement.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with lower-limb motor dysfunction (290 participants across 8 studies, 230 in the meta-analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare clinical outcomes of immediate weightbearing versus delayed weightbearing after lateral ankle ligament repair in patients with chronic ankle instability.
results_summary: Immediate weightbearing allowed patients to return to unsupported walking more quickly without negatively affecting ankle function scores, return times to normal activities, or ankle range of motion compared to delayed weightbearing. Both groups showed similar outcomes in AOFAS and Karlsson scores at follow-ups.
population_specificity: 88 participants (58 men, 30 women) with chronic lateral ankle instability, mean age 30.26 years.
effective_dosage: Immediate weightbearing with a hard ankle brace versus nonweightbearing casting for 2 weeks followed by weightbearing.

study_goal: The study aimed to assess the effect of Tongmai Yangxin Pill (TMYX) on ventricular remodeling in acute ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) patients undergoing primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PPCI).
results_summary: The study found that TMYX significantly improved left ventricular end-diastolic volume index (LVEDVI) and left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) compared to placebo at 4 and 12 weeks, but no significant differences were observed for other outcomes like left ventricular end-systolic volume (LVESV) or 6-minute walking distance (6MWD).
population_specificity: Patients with acute anterior STEMI undergoing PPCI within 10 days of symptom onset.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the BHIP prenatal diet-and-exercise intervention, which included a controlled walking program, improved emotion regulation in 22-month-old offspring.
results_summary: The study found that children exposed to the BHIP intervention showed medium to large effect size improvements in emotion regulation, as reported by parents. Larger trials were recommended to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: Pregnant individuals (>18 years, singleton pregnancy) recruited between 12 and 17 weeks gestation.
effective_dosage: Not specified (controlled walking program details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare Gait Deviation Index (GDI) and Gait Variability Index (GVI) scores measured using markerless Theia3D and marker-based motion capture systems in children with cerebral palsy (CP).
results_summary: GDI scores were significantly lower when measured using Theia3D compared to the marker-based approach and in the more affected limbs, while GVI scores showed no differences between systems or limb impairment. Theia3D adequately measured variability in spatio-temporal gait parameters but showed differences in kinematic measurements exceeding 10° in some cases.
population_specificity: Fifteen children with CP (GMFCS levels I-IV) and 24 typically developing children aged 6-18 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the biomechanical loading effects of different prosthetic feet (SACH, ESAR, N-ESAR) on individuals with unilateral transtibial amputation during fast-paced walking.
results_summary: Fast-paced walking increased sound-side loading compared to normal-paced walking, but the N-ESAR prosthesis reduced sound-side peak vertical ground reaction force and external knee adduction moment while improving distal shank power on the prosthetic side. The N-ESAR also showed a larger percentage change in biomechanical loading from normal- to fast-paced walking, possibly due to enabling faster walking speeds.
population_specificity: Individuals with unilateral transtibial amputation (UTTA), classified as K3-K4 ambulators (n=20, age 40 ± 16 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare clinical outcomes between nail-plate constructs and the plate-on-plate technique for treating proximal femoral peri-implant fractures (PFPIF), focusing on surgical time, blood loss, and functional recovery.
results_summary: The plate-on-plate technique resulted in significantly shorter surgical times and less blood loss compared to nail-plate constructs, but no significant differences were found in union time, ambulation status, or complication rates between the two groups.
population_specificity: Thirty-seven patients with PFPIF treated at a single hospital.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (surgical techniques compared, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of combined chemotherapy and surgery in treating a rare malignant triton tumor (MTT) in the distal femur, focusing on pain relief and walking ability.
results_summary: The study found that the combined treatment (surgery and chemotherapy) successfully prevented local recurrence and metastasis, allowing the patient to walk without pain 1.5 years post-surgery.
population_specificity: A 16-year-old male with MTT in the distal femur and no history of Neurofibromatosis-1.
effective_dosage: Preoperative chemotherapy: adriamycin, ifosfamide, cisplatin; postoperative chemotherapy: methotrexate plus the same agents (specific dosages not detailed).
study_duration: Treatment duration not explicitly stated; follow-up was 1.5 years post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to outline a clinical approach for diagnosing skin diseases in travelers, emphasizing risk factors like walking barefoot and other at-risk activities.
results_summary: The study identified walking barefoot as a risk factor for hookworm-related cutaneous larva migrans (CLM) and other skin conditions in travelers, but did not evaluate the safety or efficacy of walking itself.
population_specificity: Travelers, particularly those engaging in at-risk activities like walking barefoot, sun exposure, and water exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the real-world safety and efficacy of Luminor drug-coated balloons in improving outcomes for femoropopliteal revascularizations, including walking ability and quality of life.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in walking ability (measured by Walking Impairment Questionnaire scores) and quality of life, with high primary patency (87.4%) and low complication rates. The 12-month results showed 82.7% composite safety and 96.2% freedom from target lesion revascularization.
population_specificity: 542 patients (67.2% male, mean age 71.2 years) with femoropopliteal lesions, including those with diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and varying Rutherford categories.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the mental health effects of walking in a botanical garden versus interacting with goats on a farm.
results_summary: Walking in a botanical garden showed smaller but significant decreases in anxiety (13%) and increases in trust (3%) compared to goat interaction, suggesting a beneficial but less pronounced effect on mental well-being.
population_specificity: Healthy farm volunteers and garden visitors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of integrated instability resistance training and cognitive training (IRCT) versus isolated instability resistance training (IRT) on balance, gait, muscle strength, and cognitive functions in elderly women.
